description: An introduction to protein structure, enzyme kinetics, mechanism of enzyme action and allosteric regulation of enzyme activity; introduction to cell structure and function including membrane structure, membrane receptors and signal transduction, motility, and the cell cycle.
name: CELL. BIOL. & BIOCHEM.

values.comments:
This course is an introduction to protein structure, enzyme kinetics, mechanism of enzyme action and allosteric regulation of enzyme activity; introduction to cell structure and function including membrane structure, membrane receptors and signal transduction, motility, and the cell cycle.

	Students overall enjoyed the course material thoroughly, but acknowledged that the class demanded a lot of work.  Many students commented how some of the material was similar to BIOL121, except much more specific and complicated. Several students described the class as “very interesting” and “essential for anyone studying biology.”  Many students also noted, however, that the class required “a lot of memorization.”  Additionally, students found it frustrating and disorganized how the two professors “would alternate their lectures randomly,” as they had very different teaching styles.  Overall, students felt the course was “necessary, but not fun.”

	Professor Svitkina was praised for being “knowledgeable, concise, organized and clear.”  At the same time, however, students felt her lectures were “jam-packed with info,” which made it very difficult to study for her exams.  She explained the “important details,” though, which made attending her lectures worthwhile.  Overall, students felt that Professor Svitkina demanded a lot from her students—sometimes an overwhelming amount of material—but was a “direct” enough professor that she made it possible.

	Students mostly found this class to be “extremely difficult.”  It was fairly strongly recommended for majors, but not at all recommended for non-biology majors.  BIOL 101 and 102 or BIOL 121 are prerequisites for this course.  CHEM 102 or a strong high school background in chemistry is highly recommended before taking this course.
